issues.description: Method name mismatch for the farm-song method: the problem statement and UML refer to a method named printFarmSong(), but the template repository and the provided solution both declare and use singFarmSong() (and singFarmSongVerse(...)). This naming discrepancy can confuse students (the instructions ask them to implement printFarmSong(), but the starter code exposes singFarmSong()), causing them to implement the wrong method name or search for a non-existent method in the template.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across artifacts. Either update the problem statement and UML to refer to singFarmSong() (preferred, since the template and solution already use that name), or change the template/solution to provide a public printFarmSong() that delegates to the existing singFarmSong()/singFarmSongVerse(...) implementation. Ensure the task text and code use the same method name so students know which method to implement.

issues.description: The problem statement asks students to "Implement the method printFarmSong() inside Farm.java" (problem text), but the template and reference solution define and use a method named singFarmSong(). This is the same conceptual operation (print/play the Old MacDonald song for all animals) but with two different public method names. A student following the textual instruction will look for printFarmSong() in the template and tests; the provided template/solution use singFarmSong(), which creates a direct mapping confusion between the requirement and the starter/solution code.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the public method name across all artifacts. Either (A) change the problem statement to instruct students to implement singFarmSong() (recommended, since template and solution already use singFarmSong()), or (B) rename the method in the template and solution from singFarmSong() to printFarmSong(). Ensure tests and example Main.java calls are updated to use the chosen name so students can map the requirement to the provided code without extra confusion.
